metrics.name: k8s.container.ready
metrics.description: Whether a container has passed its readiness probe (0 for no, 1 for yes)

metrics.name: k8s.container.restarts
metrics.description: How many times the container has restarted in the recent past. This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

metrics.name: k8s.daemonset.desired_scheduled_nodes
metrics.description: Number of nodes that should be running the daemon pod (including nodes currently running the daemon pod)

metrics.name: k8s.daemonset.misscheduled_nodes
metrics.description: Number of nodes that are running the daemon pod, but are not supposed to run the daemon pod

metrics.name: k8s.daemonset.ready_nodes
metrics.description: Number of nodes that should be running the daemon pod and have one or more of the daemon pod running and ready

metrics.name: k8s.job.active_pods
metrics.description: The number of actively running pods for a job

metrics.name: k8s.job.desired_successful_pods
metrics.description: The desired number of successfully finished pods the job should be run with

metrics.name: k8s.job.failed_pods
metrics.description: The number of pods which reached phase Failed for a job

metrics.name: k8s.job.max_parallel_pods
metrics.description: The max desired number of pods the job should run at any given time

metrics.name: k8s.job.successful_pods
metrics.description: The number of pods which reached phase Succeeded for a job

metrics.name: k8s.container.ready
metrics.description: Whether a container has passed its readiness probe (0 for no, 1 for yes)

metrics.name: k8s.container.restarts
metrics.description: How many times the container has restarted in the recent past. This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

metrics.name: k8s.container.ready
metrics.description: Whether a container has passed its readiness probe (0 for no, 1 for yes)

metrics.name: k8s.container.restarts
metrics.description: How many times the container has restarted in the recent past. This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

metrics.description: Current phase of the pod (1 - Pending, 2 - Running, 3 - Succeeded, 4 - Failed, 5 - Unknown)

metrics.name: k8s.container.ready
metrics.description: Whether a container has passed its readiness probe (0 for no, 1 for yes)

metrics.name: k8s.container.restarts
metrics.description: How many times the container has restarted in the recent past. This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

metrics.name: k8s.container.ready
metrics.description: Whether a container has passed its readiness probe (0 for no, 1 for yes)

metrics.name: k8s.container.restarts
metrics.description: How many times the container has restarted in the recent past. This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

metrics.description: Whether a container has passed its readiness probe (0 for no, 1 for yes)

metrics.name: k8s.container.restarts
metrics.description: How many times the container has restarted in the recent past. This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

metrics.name: k8s.container.restarts
metrics.description: How many times the container has restarted in the recent past. This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

metrics.name: k8s.container.restarts
metrics.description: How many times the container has restarted in the recent past. This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

metrics.name: k8s.container.ready
metrics.description: Whether a container has passed its readiness probe (0 for no, 1 for yes)

metrics.name: k8s.container.restarts
metrics.description: How many times the container has restarted in the recent past. This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.

metrics.name: k8s.container.ready
metrics.description: Whether a container has passed its readiness probe (0 for no, 1 for yes)

metrics.name: k8s.container.restarts
metrics.description: How many times the container has restarted in the recent past. This value is pulled directly from the K8s API and the value can go indefinitely high and be reset to 0 at any time depending on how your kubelet is configured to prune dead containers. It is best to not depend too much on the exact value but rather look at it as either == 0, in which case you can conclude there were no restarts in the recent past, or > 0, in which case you can conclude there were restarts in the recent past, and not try and analyze the value beyond that.
